summary: This document contains Bureau of Prisons (BOP) health services clinical encounter records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 28-30, 2019, and a critical emergency resuscitation note from August 10, 2019. The records detail his medical complaints, chronic conditions, and the events surrounding his cardiac arrest and death in custody. This document is a series of Bureau of Prisons (BOP) health services clinical encounter notes for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering the period from July 12 to July 28, 2019. The notes detail his medical complaints, chronic conditions, and crucially, document an injury assessment on July 23, 2019, where he was found with a rope around his neck and marks on his neck, which he refused to explain, only insinuating his roommate was involved. This document contains Bureau of Prisons (BOP) health services records for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering his initial intake health screening on July 6, 2019, a history and physical on July 9, 2019, and an administrative note regarding a medication change on July 12, 2019. The records detail his medical history, vital signs, and health status while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (NYM). This document is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) health services record for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, covering his medical history, conditions, treatments, and vital signs from July 2019 to May 2020. It details his numerous health issues, medications, and a note about 'self inflicted injuries'. This document contains Bureau of Prisons health services records for Jeffrey Epstein from July-August 2019, including dental exams, psychological assessments, and suicide risk evaluations following an incident where he was found with a string around his neck. The records show Epstein's medical conditions, mental state, and interactions with prison staff while in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). A series of Bureau of Prisons clinical psychology contact notes documenting daily mental status evaluations of inmate Jeffrey Epstein while he was on psychological observation in July 2019, shortly before his death. The notes detail his complaints about conditions in the Special Housing Unit (SHU), his inability to remember how he sustained neck injuries, his sleep issues, and his interactions with attorneys and inmate companions. This document contains multiple Bureau of Prisons psychology service reports from July 2019 regarding Jeffrey Epstein's mental health status and suicide risk assessments while incarcerated at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. It details his placement on and removal from suicide watch following an incident where he was found with a string around his neck, his interactions with psychologists, and his reported fears for his safety. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychology services notes and a suicide risk assessment for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, conducted from July 9-11, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (NYM). The records detail his mental status evaluations, his denial of suicidality, his various requests and complaints about jail conditions, and his anticipation of a bail hearing. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychological assessments for Jeffrey Epstein conducted on July 8-9, 2019, while he was incarcerated at MCC-NY. It includes a suicide risk assessment, a risk of sexual abusiveness evaluation, and an intake screening. The assessments note Epstein's risk factors but conclude he was at low risk for suicide and sexual abusiveness, and he denied any mental health issues or suicidal ideation. This document contains Bureau of Prisons medical and psychological records for Jeffrey Epstein from July 2019, while he was incarcerated at MCC New York. It includes a psychological evaluation finding him mentally stable with no need for treatment, lab results, and multiple forms where he refused recommended medical examinations, including rectal/genital, eye doctor, and chest X-ray evaluations.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The subject of multiple Bureau of Prisons psychological assessments while incarcerated at MCC-NY. He is assessed for suicide risk and risk of sexual abusiveness, denies any mental health history or suicidal ideation, and discusses his legal case and background.

persons.name: Beaudouin, Robert MD
persons.context: A physician who examined Epstein on July 30, 2019, and ordered tests and medications.

persons.name: Quin, Robert MD
persons.context: A physician listed as a provider for some of Epstein's vital sign readings on July 30, 2019.

persons.name: Beaudouin
persons.context: A provider who completed a clinical encounter note for Epstein on July 12, 2019, regarding chronic care management.

persons.name: PA-C
persons.context: The healthcare provider who conducted Epstein's initial health screening on July 6, 2019, and documented his medical history and vital signs.

persons.name: Robert Beaudouin
persons.context: Listed as the prescribing doctor for one of Epstein's medications (Docusate Sodium) in the medication summary.

persons.name: Darlene Imeri
persons.context: Conducted suicide risk assessments and competency evaluations for Epstein on multiple dates in July and August 2019, documenting his mental status and risk factors.

persons.name: PhD/Chief Psychologist
persons.context: The on-call and chief psychologist who was notified of the suicide watch placement, conducted SHU reviews, and had clinical contacts with Epstein regarding his complaints about conditions.

persons.name: PsyD
persons.context: A psychologist (Doctor of Psychology) who conducted clinical interviews with Epstein, assessed his mental status, and documented his complaints and observations.

persons.name: Nick
persons.context: Epstein's former cellmate in the SHU; Epstein requested to speak with him to see if he could provide information about the incident that caused Epstein's neck injuries.

persons.name: Ph.D.
persons.context: A Bureau of Prisons psychologist who conducted the post-suicide watch report on July 24, 2019, interviewed Epstein, and recommended his step-down to Psychological Observation.

persons.name: Operations Lt.
persons.context: The corrections officer who contacted the on-call psychologist at about 2 AM on July 23, 2019, to inform them Epstein was being placed on suicide watch.

persons.name: Captain
persons.context: A prison official notified by the PsyD psychologist about the log book notation where Epstein allegedly said his cellmate tried to kill him.

persons.name: Imen Darlene PsyD
persons.context: A psychologist who attempted to see Epstein for a Psych Observation Follow-Up on July 11, 2019, but he was in an attorney conference.

persons.name: Miller, Elissa PhD/Chief
persons.context: Named as the generator of the suicide risk assessment document on July 10, 2019. Likely the same as the 'PhD/Chief Psychologist' authoring the notes.

persons.name: PsyD/PhD
persons.context: A psychologist who conducted the intake screening and risk of sexual abusiveness assessment for Epstein on July 8, 2019.

persons.name: Dr. [Redacted]
persons.context: A psychologist from the BOP Central Office consulted by the PhD/Chief Psychologist regarding Epstein's risk factors for suicidality.

persons.name: Epstein's brother
persons.context: Mentioned by Epstein as his only family, with whom he stated he does not have a close relationship.

persons.name: Epstein's attorney
persons.context: Mentioned by Epstein, who expressed confidence in him, described him as competent, and requested to meet with him.

persons.name: Inmate Brown
persons.context: Mentioned once in the psychological evaluation in the context of denying any familial history of suicide behaviors. Likely a reference error where 'Brown' was used instead of 'Epstein'.

connections.description: Epstein was evaluated and treated by Dr. Beaudouin for various medical complaints while in custody.
Dr. Quin is listed as a provider for some of Epstein's recorded vital signs.
PA-C conducted the initial health screening and assessment of inmate Epstein upon his intake into BOP custody.
Clinical relationship where Imeri, as a prison psychologist, assessed Epstein's suicide risk, mental status, and competency for disciplinary proceedings.
Clinical therapeutic relationship where the psychologist assessed Epstein's mental status and provided interventions.
Clinical therapeutic relationship where the psychologist conducted daily mental status evaluations.
Epstein was previously housed with Nick in the SHU and wanted to speak with him to gain information about the neck injury incident.
Clinical therapeutic relationship. The chief psychologist conducted multiple sessions with Epstein, addressed his complaints about prison conditions, and provided supportive interventions.

Epstein described his cellmate as 'agitated,' claimed the cellmate called him a 'pedophile,' and expressed fear for his safety if returned to the cell with him. The cellmate is implicated in the neck injury incident.
Professional reporting relationship. The PsyD psychologist notified the Captain about the discrepancy between Epstein's interview and the suicide watch log notation.
Clinical assessment relationship. The Ph.D. psychologist conducted a detailed post-suicide watch interview, assessed his risk factors, and made housing recommendations.
Clinical relationship where the chief psychologist evaluates Epstein's mental health and suicide risk.
Clinical relationship where PsyD Darlene attempted to conduct a follow-up observation.
Epstein identified his brother as his only family but stated they do not have a close relationship.
Epstein expressed confidence in his attorney, described him as competent, and requested to meet with him.
The PhD/Chief Psychologist consulted with Dr. [Redacted] from Central Office regarding Epstein's risk factors for suicidality.

events.title: Epstein's Cardiac Arrest and Resuscitation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) at approximately 06:35. Correctional officers initiated CPR. Paramedics arrived, intubated him, and administered epinephrine and sodium bicarbonate. He was transported to a local emergency room with CPR in progress. The note describes him as cold, with bruising around the neck and fixed, dilated pupils.

events.title: Medical Evaluation Referred by Warden
events.description: Epstein was evaluated in the chronic care clinic after being referred by the warden. He reported being without his medications for about a week, numbness in his right arm, sleep issues due to lack of a CPAP machine, and various chronic conditions. New medications and tests were ordered.

events.title: Report of Right Arm Numbness
events.description: Epstein reported to medical staff that he woke up with a lack of control over his right arm for a few minutes. He was evaluated, and no acute neurological deficits were found at that time.

events.title: Epstein Found with Neck Injury
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell (Special Housing Unit Z05-Cell 124 L) with a rope around his neck, sitting on the floor. He had a circular line of erythema (redness) at the base of his neck. He told medical staff he did not know how it happened, stating 'I do not know. Just went to drink a little water and wake up snorting.' He was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein Insinuates Roommate Involvement
events.description: During a follow-up medical exam for his neck injury, Epstein insinuated to a healthcare provider that his roommate 'had to do with what happened to me,' but refused to elaborate or say anything further.

events.title: Medical Notification to Operations Lieutenant
events.description: A Mid-Level Practitioner (MLP) notified the Operations Lieutenant (OP LT) regarding Epstein's statement about the events from two nights prior (the neck injury incident).

events.title: Epstein's Initial BOP Health Screening
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes a comprehensive health screening upon intake at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (NYM). The screening includes medical history, infectious disease risk assessment, vital signs (noting elevated blood pressure), and administration of a PPD test for tuberculosis.

events.title: Epstein's History and Physical Exam
events.description: A more detailed history and physical examination is performed on Epstein. It notes his personal history (banker, traveled to Paris before arrest), family history, and a current issue with constipation for which medication is prescribed.

events.title: Epstein's Medication Change Request
events.description: An administrative note records that inmate Epstein requested to change his constipation medication from bisacodyl to docusate sodium (Colace). The order was changed accordingly.

events.title: Epstein's Initial BOP Health Intake
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein's health intake and assessment begins upon his incarceration, recording initial vital signs, health problems, and immunizations.

events.title: Epstein's Medical Transfer
events.description: A medical transfer form is generated for Jeffrey Epstein, listing his active health problems and medications for transport.

events.title: Epstein found with string around neck
events.description: Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck, leading to an incident report for tattooing or self-mutilation and subsequent psychological evaluations.

events.title: Dental health assessment
events.description: Epstein received a dental examination at MCC New York documenting various health conditions including sleep apnea, chlamydia history, and dental issues.

events.title: Suicide risk assessment after court incident
events.description: Psychological evaluation conducted after US Marshals asked Epstein to sign a form noting he had 'suicidal tendencies' following his return from court.

events.title: Competency evaluation for disciplinary process
events.description: Psychological assessment to determine Epstein's competency to proceed with disciplinary proceedings related to the July 23 incident with the string around his neck.

events.title: Psychological follow-up session
events.description: Follow-up clinical contact where Epstein reported feeling okay, wanting to go to general population, and spending time with his attorneys.

events.title: Epstein Clinical Observation - Complaints about SHU
events.description: Epstein seen on psychological observation; in good spirits but denies memory of neck injury event; complains SHU is a 'punishment cell,' dangerous, noisy, and smelly; denies suicidality.

events.title: Epstein Requests to Contact Cellmate
events.description: Epstein seen on observation; smiling and joking; complains about legal visit procedures and constipation; reports no memory of neck injury event; asks to speak with former cellmate 'Nick' to see if he can trigger memory.

events.title: Epstein Reports Sleep Deprivation and Anxiety
events.description: Epstein reports sleeping only 30 minutes per night for 5 days prior to neck injury due to SHU noise; anxious about returning to SHU; feels dehydrated; denies suicidal ideation.

events.title: Epstein Reports Numbness and Toilet Incident
events.description: Epstein reports numbness in right arm and neck; describes an aversive incident where a toilet flushed for 45 minutes, causing agitation and preventing sleep; suggests he may have traits on the autism spectrum.

events.title: Epstein Requests to Stay in Hospital Area
events.description: Epstein seen on observation; reports memory may be impaired due to sleep apnea; expects CPAP machine; requests to remain in hospital area where it is 'safe' for a week but is told he will return to SHU.

events.title: Epstein Found with String Around Neck
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck in the early morning hours. This precipitated his placement on Suicide Watch. The origin of the injury is unclear, with conflicting reports from Epstein (memory loss) and log notes (claiming his cellmate tried to kill him).

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment (Moderate Risk)
events.description: Psychologist (PsyD) conducted a suicide risk assessment, finding moderate acute suicide risk due to the unexplained neck injury and high-profile case, despite Epstein's denials. He was ordered to remain on Suicide Watch.

events.title: Removal from Suicide Watch
events.description: Following a subsequent assessment by psychologist (Ph.D.), Epstein was stepped down from Suicide Watch to Psychological Observation. He was assessed as having low acute suicide risk, having adamantly denied suicidality and expressed future orientation toward his legal case.

events.title: Placement in SHU (Administrative Segregation)
events.description: Epstein was placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) on administrative detention status.

events.title: Legal Visit
events.description: Epstein attended a legal visit after being provided a shower, as noted in the post-suicide watch report.

events.title: Epstein Returns from Court
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein returned to the Metropolitan Correctional Center from a court proceeding in the evening. His return triggered a precautionary psychological observation due to risk factors associated with his case.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: A formal suicide risk assessment was conducted on Epstein at 7:30 a.m. He was found to have a low acute suicide risk and an absent chronic risk. He denied any suicidal ideation.

events.title: Clinical Intervention Session
events.description: Epstein was seen for a psychological observation contact. He presented numerous concerns and requests about his housing, medical care, uniform, and property. He was provided supportive intervention.

events.title: Failed Follow-Up Attempt
events.description: A psychologist attempted to see Epstein for a follow-up observation but he was in an attorney conference.

events.title: Upcoming Bail Hearing
events.description: Epstein stated he had a bail hearing scheduled for the Monday following the assessment (July 15, 2019). He expressed hope for release but acknowledged logistical delays.

events.title: Court Proceeding and Initial Risk Assessment
events.description: Epstein had a court proceeding which could have given him bad news regarding his legal situation. Upon his return to jail, BOP staff were instructed to notify psychology. A risk of sexual abusiveness assessment and intake screening were conducted.

events.title: Previous Incarceration in Palm Beach
events.description: Epstein reported he had previously served time in Palm Beach County jail on charges of soliciting prostitution.

events.title: Upcoming Bail Hearing
events.description: Epstein reported he was going to have a bail hearing on the Monday following the assessment and believed he was going to be released from jail.

events.title: Psychological Evaluation of Epstein
events.description: A psychological evaluation conducted at MCC New York finds Jeffrey Epstein appears calm, controlled, and cooperative. He denies any history of mental health symptoms or treatment and is assessed as Care Level 1 (no significant impairment or need for regular intervention).

events.title: Blood Work Collection
events.description: Blood is collected from Jeffrey Epstein for comprehensive chemistry, hematology, and serology panels, including an HIV test which returns negative.

events.title: Refusal of Rectal/Genital Exam
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signs a form refusing the recommended rectal and genital examination, acknowledging the risk of an undetected and untreated medical condition.

events.title: Refusal of Chest X-Ray
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signs a form refusing a recommended routine chest X-ray for a 66-year-old male with no past medical history, acknowledging the risk of worsening condition if there are any findings.

events.title: Refusal of Eye Doctor Evaluation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein signs a form (twice in the document) refusing a recommended eye doctor evaluation, acknowledging the inability to diagnose current ophthalmologic diseases.

events.title: Dental Examination
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein undergoes an initial dental examination at MCC New York. Findings include good oral hygiene and no urgent treatment needs.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (NYM - likely New York Metropolitan)
Mount Sinai Hospital (referenced for past appendicitis in 1990)
NEW YORK MCC (Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York), City/State/Zip: NEW YORK, New York 10007
SHU (Special Housing Unit) at MCC New York
Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (MCC NYM / NYM)
Special Housing Unit (SHU) at MCC NYM
Hospital / Psychological Observation area at MCC NYM
Palm Beach County jail (mentioned as past incarceration location)
MCC New York (Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York)
U.S. Medical Center for Federal Prisons, 1900 W. Sunshine Street, Springfield, MO 65807
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on the morning of August 10, 2019, with CPR already in progress by correctional officers.
The emergency medical note from August 10 describes Epstein as having 'circumferential bruising around the neck' and 'posterior mottling' when found.

In the days before his death (July 28-30), Epstein reported medical issues including right arm numbness, lack of sleep due to missing his CPAP machine, and being without his prescribed medications for about a week.
Epstein had multiple chronic health conditions documented, including hypertension, sleep apnea, prediabetes, hyperlipidemia, and low back pain.
The document is a series of Bureau of Prisons health service records, indicating official medical monitoring and treatment during his incarceration.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his prison cell with a rope around his neck, resulting in visible neck injuries, and was placed on suicide watch.
Epstein repeatedly refused to explain how the neck injury occurred, telling medical staff 'I do not know' and 'I am not going to say anything.'
During a July 24, 2019 exam, Epstein insinuated his cellmate/roommate was responsible for his injuries, stating 'I think my room mate had to do with what happened to me.'
The Bureau of Prisons medical staff formally notified the Operations Lieutenant about Epstein's statement regarding the incident.

The records document Epstein's chronic health conditions, including hyperlipidemia, severe lower back pain, neuralgia, and obstructive sleep apnea, for which he used a CPAP machine prior to his arrest.
Jeffrey Epstein's BOP medical records from July 6-12, 2019, show he was alert, oriented, and denied any history of mental health treatment, suicide attempts, or substance abuse.
Epstein reported having 10 or more female sexual partners in the last 5 years, sometimes used condoms, and had a history of chlamydia treated in 2015.
During his intake on July 6, 2019, Epstein's blood pressure was elevated (164/90, 155/83), though he denied a history of hypertension. He was asymptomatic.
Epstein reported traveling to Paris for three weeks immediately prior to his arrest.
The records indicate multiple provider names and cosigners were redacted pursuant to FOIA exemptions (b)(6) and (b)(7).

Jeffrey Epstein's BOP medical records list multiple health conditions including hyperlipidemia, sleep apnea, hypertension, prediabetes, low back pain, neuralgia, and an 'injury, unspecified' noted as 'RIO self inflicted injuries.'
Epstein was prescribed regular insulin via a sliding scale in July/August 2019, indicating management of elevated blood glucose levels.
The records note Epstein had a C-Pap machine for sleep apnea and was assigned a lower bunk restriction in his cell.
A dietary restriction for 'FISH ALLERGIES' is recorded, though the allergies section states 'No Known Allergies.'
The document timeframe (July 2019 to May 2020) covers the period immediately before, during, and after Epstein's death in August 2019.

Epstein was found with a string loosely tied around his neck on July 23, 2019, but claimed not to remember how it happened, leading to uncertainty about whether he placed it there himself or someone else did.
Psychological assessments identified Epstein's risk factors for suicide including high-profile crime, sex offender status, lack of family connections, current physical pain, and sleep problems.
Epstein was evaluated as competent to proceed with disciplinary proceedings related to the July 23 incident, despite his claims of not remembering the event.
Medical records show Epstein had a history of chlamydia (treated in 2015), sleep apnea, and various dental issues including moderate to advanced gingival recession.
Epstein spent significant time with his attorneys in the attorney conference room and reported that his lawyers visited him often, providing emotional support.
Jeffrey Epstein was on psychological observation in the Bureau of Prisons from at least July 25 to July 29, 2019.
Epstein repeatedly claimed he could not remember the incident that caused marks and a scab on his neck, suggesting memory impairment from sleep apnea or other causes.
Epstein expressed significant anxiety about returning to the Special Housing Unit (SHU), citing noise, smells, feeling punished, and concerns about safety.
Epstein requested to speak with his former SHU cellmate 'Nick' to see if he could provide information about the neck injury incident.
Clinical staff consistently noted Epstein denied current suicidal or self-harm ideation, often stating he wanted to live to fight his legal case.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his prison cell with a string loosely tied around his neck, resulting in a circular scar. He claimed to have no memory of the incident.
Suicide watch logs indicated Epstein told staff his cellmate tried to kill him, a claim he did not repeat to psychologists during interviews.
Epstein expressed fear for his safety regarding his cellmate, who he said called him a 'pedophile' and was reading newspaper articles about him.

Despite the incident, Epstein consistently and adamantly denied current or past suicidal ideation, intent, or plans to psychologists, stating he had 'lots to do' for his legal case and a 'wonderful life.'

Bureau of Prisons psychologists assessed Epstein with both risk factors (high-profile crime, sex offender status, fear for safety) and protective factors (future orientation, denial of suicidality), leading to his removal from suicide watch to psychological observation within 31 hours.
Jeffrey Epstein was evaluated and found to have a low acute suicide risk and absent chronic suicide risk just weeks before his death.
Epstein explicitly and repeatedly denied any past or present suicidal ideation, intention, or plan during these evaluations.
Epstein was on a precautionary psychological observation status due to risk factors including his high-profile case, sex offense charges, pre-trial status, and a recent court proceeding.
Epstein made numerous specific complaints and requests regarding his jail conditions, including housing, medication (Colace), uniforms, and access to recreation and property.
The documents note Epstein's only family was a brother with whom he did not have a close relationship, but he claimed to have a support system of friends and associates in the community.

On July 9, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was assessed by BOP psychologists as having a low acute suicide risk and an absent chronic suicide risk, despite having risk factors like a high-profile case and sex offense charges.
Epstein adamantly denied any past or present suicidal ideation, intention, or plan, and denied any history of mental health treatment or substance abuse.
A separate assessment on July 8, 2019, judged Epstein to be at a low risk of sexual abusiveness within the facility, based on his history of prior sexual abuse perpetration in the community.
Epstein reported his only family was his brother, with whom he did not have a close relationship, but stated he had a support system of friends and associates in the community.
The documents show BOP staff were proactively monitoring Epstein due to his high-profile status and legal situation, placing him on precautionary psychological observation after court appearances.
A psychological evaluation on July 8, 2019, found Jeffrey Epstein to be mentally stable, calm, cooperative, and not in distress, with no need for scheduled mental health follow-up.
Epstein refused multiple recommended medical examinations in July 2019, including a rectal and genital exam, an eye doctor evaluation, and a routine chest X-ray.
Lab results from blood collected on July 9, 2019, showed elevated cholesterol and triglycerides, and a negative HIV test.
The document notes Epstein was previously incarcerated for three months for prostitution and was currently charged with sex trafficking.
Staff names (e.g., psychologists, doctors, counselors) are redacted pursuant to FOIA exemptions (b)(6) and (b)(7).
